title: Albrecht Dürer Was an Artist on the Move
summary: A new exhibition explores the artistic and personal impact of travel on a Renaissance master. Albrecht Dürer was perhaps the most accomplished artist of the Northern Renaissance, the creator of stunning paintings like "Self-Portrait" and exquisite prints like "Melancholia I." He was also, as a new exhibition reveals, an inveterate traveler whose journeys influenced his ambitions, his art and his impact. "Dürer Was Here: A Journey Becomes Legend," opening July 18 at the Suermondt-Ludwig-Museum in Aachen, Germany, commemorates his visit there in October 1520. A smaller version of the show will be on view at London's National Gallery in November.

MY FIRST NIGHT in Mykonos, a few weeks ago, the whitewashed hillside windmills overlooking the port were still, but I had all the fresh air I craved merely by being on the island. I was sitting on the stone steps of a seaside bar sipping a sundowner with a friend who had just arrived from New York City. I felt giddy, despite the occasional pang of doubt about abandoning over a year's worth of deeply drilled-in safety precautions.

summary: The founder of startup Joby Aviation believes vertical takeoff and landing vehicles will soon be a 'cheaper, faster, safer' and greener way of commuting. Getting water, he explains, meant making sure the pump was running. Plowing the garden required checking the oil in the tractor. There was no electricity, so to use a computer, he had to know how to keep the batteries and inverter humming properly.

title: From Balenciaga to Jean Paul Gaultier: The 14 Best Looks of The Fall 2021 Couture Season
summary: Here's the best of the fall couture collections, including looks from Dior, Schiaparelli and Fendi.. The fall 2021 couture shows were full of fresh starts. They began on Monday evening in the Marais district of Paris, when Alaïa's newly appointed creative director, Belgian designer Pieter Mulier, debuted his first collection for the French house in front of an in-person audience. The collection was made of 33 ready-to-wear looks and 10 couture looks focused on sleek, body-conscious silhouettes including a long corseted, strapless dress in black leather. Jean Paul Gaultier was also looking for a new perspective this season and handed over the atelier keys to Chitose Abe, who is also the creative director of Sacai. Abe made her first foray into haute couture as a guest designer for this season only. The collection was a combination of Gaultier's signature looks mixed with Abe's playful aesthetic, demonstrated through pieces like reconstructed pinstripe tailoring and tattoo prints. Later in the week, designer Demna Gvasalia unveiled the first haute couture collection for Balenciaga since its founder Cristóbal Balenciaga closed the atelier 53 years ago. The revival included all-black tailoring, expansive taffeta silhouettes, intricate embroideries and striking denim ensembles. Elsewhere, there were brightly colored tweeds and delicate cropped tops at Chanel, and oversize jewel-embellished gowns at Viktor & Rolf. Iris van Herpen's presentation featured world-champion skydiver Domitille Kiger jumping out of a plane in a look from the new collection. Below, we've chosen a selection of our favorite looks from the couture season.

title: 'The Howe Dynasty' Review: An Imperial Family
summary: The brothers led Britain's military campaigns in America while their sister shrewdly campaigned for them from London.. On the hot afternoon of July 6, 1758, advance troops of a vast Anglo-American army probed through forest toward the French fortress of Ticonderoga, in what is now upstate New York. As skirmishing suddenly erupted, the woods crackled with gunfire. Casualties were minimal but momentous: Shot through the heart, and among the first to fall, was the army's charismatic second-in-command, British Brig. Gen. George Augustus, Lord Howe.

title: 'The Letters of Shirley Jackson' Review: The Artist as Mad Housewife
summary: In her correspondence, she presents her family as a chaotic circus, and casts herself as the ringmaster.. In spring of 1959, Shirley Jackson wrote an imploring letter to her agent explaining why she wasn't going to be able to finish her next novel-the paranormal classic "The Haunting of Hill House"-before the deadline promised to Viking Press. First, she said, each of her four children caught the flu and then passed it to her husband, the literary critic Stanley Edgar Hyman. Her third child, Sarah, while recovering, stepped on a nail and needed a tetanus booster. Jackson had to apply for licenses for the family dogs and one of their many cats picked up an infection ("Have you ever tried to feed sulfa pills to a large and still strong cat?"). Then the furnace broke in their old house in North Bennington, Vt., and after that the plumbing backed up from a clogged septic tank that couldn't be readily repaired because the ground was frozen solid. Water was rationed for the brushing of teeth and a method was devised of cleaning dishes off the back porch with a squirt gun.

title: 'To Walk Alone in the Crowd' Review: The Rhythm of His Footsteps
summary: A word-drunk ramble through the modern city, echoing literary predecessors from Baudelaire to Poe.. What is a book? I'm not referring to the physical object, the codex. What interests me is the blood and beat of language, the dynamic between the writer and the work. Antonio Muñoz Molina's "To Walk Alone in the Crowd" (FSG, 432 pages, $30) is a case in point. It's a novel in the form of a collage or a scrapbook, a collection of impressions that moves from Madrid to Paris to Lisbon and back again, before ending up in New York.

title: How to Solve America's Wild Deer Problem? Eat Them
summary: The deer population in the U.S. keeps growing, taking a toll on wild lands and suburban gardens. Regulated commercial hunting and expanding the venison market could be the solution.. Before Europeans came to America, there were an estimated 30 million wild deer in what is now the eastern U.S. By 1900 that figure had fallen by 99% due to unrestricted hunting, and conservationists made it their mission to protect deer from extinction. They might have succeeded too well. Today the wild deer population has rebounded to precolonization levels, becoming a nuisance to suburban homeowners who find deer invading their yards and gardens.

title: Disney's French Revolution, and What It Might Mean for a Theme Park Near You

title: Xi's Triumph Is China's Tragedy-and Ours
summary: In its 100th year, the Party is no more. There is only the personal dictatorship of Xi Jinping.. I read in your editorial "100 Years of Chinese Communism" (July 1) that "the 95 million Party members have special privileges and rule over 1.4 billion by the threat of arrest and ruin for dissent." Not long ago this was accurate-not for all Party members but certainly for the Party bosses of villages, towns, cities and provinces, including some (not Beijing) of the directly controlled megacities such as Chongqing, where Bo Xilai (now imprisoned) was once all-powerful, and later Sun Zhengcai (now in prison too) still had some power. They ruled over millions, while Politburo members as such, and even some Central Committee members, had spheres of influence and actually decided things.

title: How Much Are Prices Up? Here's One Family's Day-to-Day Expenses.
summary: Food, gas, streaming: The Galbraiths are feeling the nation's inflation, which has been driven higher as demand comes back and as supply problems caused by the pandemic linger. title: Anthony Comstock: Wronged by History
summary: The infamous censor was entirely justified in most of his prosecutions of pornographers, abortionists and brothel-keepers.. I was gobsmacked to see Charlotte Gray describe Ida C. Craddock as a "sexologist" and "lay scholar in comparative religion" in her review of Amy Sohn's "The Man Who Hated Women" ("Sex and the Censor," Bookshelf, July 3). Craddock was a crackpot who believed she was married to a ghost named Soph, with whom she had noisy intercourse that frequently woke up the neighbors. This "marriage" was not some metaphor for spiritual ecstasy but a genuine delusion, judging from her diary's descriptions of their many sexual positions. She called their congress "wissening," for "growing wise." Anthony Comstock was entirely justified in going after this pitiable but transparently mad woman and her sex manuals, as he was in most of his prosecutions of pornographers, abortionists and brothel-keepers.

title: Delta Variant's Surge Puts Europe's Summer Reopening at Risk
summary: Continent fears the strain's rise in Spain and Portugal could signal a new wave of contagion that forces countries to bring back more controls. title: When Money Is No Object
summary: Sure, using a credit card is easy, but paying with invisible money makes saving harder and spending easier. People behaved differently when they saved-and spent-cold, hard cash.. title: This Steinbrenner Doesn't Like Change-Even as the Yankees Slide
summary: The Bronx Bombers are mired in a rut unlike anything the franchise has experienced in more than a quarter-century, but the owner has no plans to alter course. Hal Steinbrenner was never going to be his father. George Steinbrenner ran the New York Yankees with a lack of impulse control and love of chaos for nearly four decades. His son is averse to his dad's trademarks: outlandish proclamations in the press, lavish spending that borders on recklessness and hasty personnel changes spurred by wild fits of rage.

title: As Delta Variant Spreads, China Lacks Data on Its Covid-19 Vaccines

title: The Unending Trial of Sacco and Vanzetti
summary: A century ago, the murder conviction of two Italian immigrants set off a worldwide protest movement and revealed a polarized America. A century ago this week, on the evening of July 14, 1921, a verdict was announced in the murder trial of Nicola Sacco and Bartolomeo Vanzetti. The complex trial, held at the courthouse in Dedham, Mass., had lasted seven weeks and involved 167 witnesses, with confusing ballistics reports and testimony in Spanish and Italian. Deliberations were expected to drag on for a day or more, but just hours after closing arguments the jury pronounced the men guilty, and they were sentenced to death. Sacco, a 30-year-old shoemaker, cried out in Italian, "Sono innocente!" ("I am innocent!"). Vanzetti, a 33-year-old fishmonger, seemed stunned.

title: Mysteries: 'Razorblade Tears' Review
summary: Two fathers join in a mission of revenge when their sons are murdered.. Ike Randolph and Buddy Lee Jenkins, the protagonists of S.A. Cosby's "Razorblade Tears" (Flatiron, 319 pages, $26.99), are both ex-convicts living in Virginia but otherwise seem to have little in common. Ike, a married black man with a successful landscaping business, has lived the straight life for 15 years. Buddy Lee, a white man who lives alone in a trailer, can't always pay his rent. But Ike and Buddy Lee are joined by fate as the fathers of two young men who married each other and have now been slain together, execution-style.

title: Children's Books: In a Mystical Landscape, Anything Can Happen
summary: A compendium of Greenland's Inuit culture places readers in a realm of icy waters and shape-shifting animals.. There's something pleasantly disconcerting about the way the past looks when we view it through folk tales. The old stories reveal ways of thinking and living that are strange to us yet also recognizable. We are like people looking down through murky waters, seeing half-identifiable shapes moving far below in the deep. This is perhaps the feeling parents and children will get from Gunvor Bjerre's retellings of 35 stories from Greenland's Inuit culture in "The Man of the Moon" (Inhabit Media, 187 pages, $29.95), a collection drawn from the work of 19th-century anthropologist Knud Rasmussen and translated into English by Charlotte Barslund.

title: 'Tall Men, Short Shorts' Review: A Supreme Basketball Court
summary: The Celtics, the Lakers and a young sportswriter's memories of giants.. The shorts they wore truly were short. When their NBA teams traveled to distant cities, the players picked up their bags at the airport carousel themselves. They had roommates. The reporters who covered them smoked, and when they worried about finding the Western Union office to send their stories back to their newspapers, they consulted a phone book.

title: Credit Suisse Adds Risk Role to Prevent Another Archegos
summary: New position will keep track of dangers building up in the investment positions of clients that could spring back on the Swiss bank. Credit Suisse Group AG took fresh steps to tackle its risk management in the wake of the $5.5 billion loss from family office Archegos Capital, with the creation of a new role that will police the effect of market moves on clients' trading positions.

title: Five Best: Books on WASPs
summary: Selected by Michael Knox Beran, the author of the forthcoming book 'WASPS: The Splendors and Miseries of an American Aristocracy.'. By Louis Auchincloss (1964)

title: 'Checkmate in Berlin' Review: Breaking the Blockade
summary: After Stalin cut road and rail connections, West Berlin needed thousands of tons of supplies daily.. The occupation of ravaged Berlin by the triumphant Americans, British and Russians in the summer of 1945 inscribed a coda to World War II in Europe, but it was also the first skirmish in the Cold War that in many respects is still going on. For most adult Americans, postwar Berlin is a flickery newsreel of the 1948 Allied airlift, the construction of the wall sealing off the Russian sector in 1961, and its joyous destruction 28 years later as the Soviet empire began to implode. Those fading memories are faint reflections of the dramatic struggle for Berlin, especially in those first years.

title: Is It Coming Home? After 55 Years of Pain, England Can't Believe Its Soccer Team Is Winning
summary: An improbable march through the Euro 2020 tournament leaves fans struggling to process their good fortune; 'we're so used to losing'. LONDON-As England prepared for its European Championship semifinal against Denmark, Samantha Nation wasn't nervous about how the night would unfold. A lifetime of supporting the Three Lions had convinced her: England was about to lose.

title: 'Barbara Hepworth' Review: Woman of Stone and Bronze
summary: Hepworth faced down the sexism endemic to her times and bristled at being called 'frail and reserved.'. Ablack-and-white photo of the British sculptor Barbara Hepworth, spread across two pages in Eleanor Clayton's new biography of the artist, neatly sums up her place in the canon of 20th-century art. Small and fragile-looking yet with a sphinxlike smile on her weathered face, Hepworth, 65 at the time, is surrounded by massive stone sculptures, some more than twice her height, on the occasion of her retrospective at the Tate Gallery in 1968. One can think of few women of her generation who attempted this kind of large-scale statement in obdurate materials like stone and bronze, and fewer still who were honored with overviews of their work at major museums.

title: A French Home That Whispers Unfashionable Chic
summary: Fashion executive Barbara Boccara, known for French-girl flair, tapped Belgian architect Nicolas Schuybroek to bring a quiet minimalism to her Paris apartment.. Barbara Boccara, whose knack for translating casual French style into marketable looks is well known to international fashion watchers, is wearing jeans, an olive-green hoodie with jeweled buttons at the shoulder and soot-black eye makeup as she gives a Zoom tour of her new home in Paris. The apartment, on one of the broad avenues radiating from the Arc de Triomphe, is a five-minute walk from Boccara's office at Ba&sh (rhymes with "posh"), the French fashion label she founded in 2003 with Sharon Krief, her best friend then and now.

title: Luxury Watches Are Badly Set for Investors
summary: Demand for the most expensive Swiss timepieces is booming, but getting access to them is tricky. The few Swiss watch brands that haven't been troubled by the pandemic are the hardest ones to invest in.

title: What Some CFOs Are Doing to Fight Inflation
summary: Higher prices, cost-savings programs and hedging are among tools finance chiefs can use as expenses rise and buying power of dollar drops. Finance chiefs across industries are facing higher costs as the economic rebound drives up demand for raw materials, components, energy and transportation. Wages are also on the rise, adding to the expenses executives need to cover.

title: Richard Branson's Virgin Galactic Flight Kick-Starts Space Tourism
summary: Entrepreneur's journey to the edge of space could bolster interest in trips, but widespread travel there is probably still years off. Space tourism is trying to take off.

title: Fixing Climate Change Isn't the Central Bank's Job
summary: The ECB joins the fight against climate change, but there are problems posed by mixing environmental mandates with financial regulation enforced by unaccountable institutions. For central banks, a task as momentous as fixing climate change may be one job too many.

title: Holding Tokyo Olympics Without Fans Could Hurt Performance, Organizer Says
summary: Decision to bar spectators means eight venues built specifically for the Games at a cost of around $3 billion will be near empty. TOKYO-The chief organizer of the Tokyo Olympics raised concerns that athletes' performance could suffer because of the ban on spectators after one competitor said the move contributed to his decision to pull out.

title: Kim Jong Un's Covid-19 Go-To Move-Finger Wagging
summary: North Korean dictator has demoted officials, criticized technocrats as the country struggles with pandemic. SEOUL-Kim Jong Un, more so than his predecessors, has spread out responsibility among an elite group of North Korean government officials. Now, facing the worst home-front crisis of his nearly decadelong reign, the young dictator is making sure to share the blame.

title: Utilities Pay for Coal-Plant Closures by Issuing Bonds
summary: Companies use securitization to fund the closures, while cutting greenhouse gases and often lowering consumers' bills. A new twist on an old financial tool is helping electric utilities shut down money-losing coal-fired power plants, cutting greenhouse gas emissions and often lowering costs for consumers.

title: Philip Morris Buys Inhaled-Medicine Company Amid Health Push
summary: Tobacco maker says purchase of Vectura would help its expansion beyond tobacco products. Philip Morris International Inc. agreed to buy Vectura Group PLC, a U.K. pharmaceuticals business specializing in inhaled medicines, for $1.24 billion in cash, bolstering its push to expand beyond tobacco and nicotine.

title: Why Aren't Millions of Unemployed Americans Finding Jobs?
summary: Resume Subscription. More than nine million Americans said in May that they wanted jobs and couldn't find them. Companies said they had more than nine million jobs open that weren't filled, a record high.

title: Meme Stock Fantasy Becomes a Reality for GameStop, AMC
summary: The hot companies of the moment are converting hype into real value, following a Wall Street tradition practiced by Tesla, AOL, Cisco and others. But true believers will pay for it.. If you really, truly believe in meme stocks, clap your hands.

title: To Keep Clear of Heatstroke, Pay Attention to This Metric
summary: As the wet-bulb temperature climbs, the body loses its ability to cool itself with sweat. The danger heat poses to human health depends on the body's ability to cool itself, and humidity makes the job more difficult.

title: Regional Fed Boards Not Diverse Enough, Report Says
summary: The local boards don't reflect the country as a whole, though most directors are supposed to represent the public, says report from Center for Popular Democracy's Fed Up campaign. White men from the financial sector and big businesses continue to be overly represented on the boards overseeing the 12 regional Federal Reserve Banks, despite some progress on improving the boards' diversity, a new report said.

title: Childhood Antipoverty Programs Face Narrow Path in Congress
summary: Democrats feel pressure to keep reconciliation package under $3 trillion. EXPANSIVE CHILD ANTIPOVERTY PROGRAMS are at the center of Democrats' work on a massive reconciliation package, but most of the party's proposals, even from committee chairs and party leaders, are likely to be left on the cutting room floor. With pressure to keep the overall package price tag under $3 trillion, or perhaps lower, the only train leaving the station might be an extension of Biden's expanded Child Tax Credit, and even that might only be temporary to keep costs down.

title: Schools Face Quandary Over Stimulus Cash
summary: Communities debate plans for stimulus dollars as educators try to make long-term gains with the short-term funds. This summer, school-district administrators are asking their communities to ponder an unusual question: What do we do with all of this money?

title: American Frackers Show Restraint as Oil Tops $70
summary: Shale companies, flush with cash, are paying off debt and sharing with investors rather than drilling more. Shale companies pumped with abandon anytime oil prices rose sharply last decade. But as crude tops $70 a barrel, they are barely doing enough to sustain U.S. production.

title: Pakistan, After Rooting for Afghanistan's Taliban, Faces a Blowback
summary: Islamabad wants a negotiated agreement, fears that outright Taliban takeover would galvanize Pakistani jihadists. ISLAMABAD-For two decades, a large part of the Pakistani security establishment rooted for the Taliban in the Afghan war. Now that the Taliban are taking over vast tracts of the country and seem to be on the cusp of seizing power, panic is spreading through Pakistan's halls of power.

title: Suspects in Killing of Haiti's President Arrested in Taiwan's Embassy
summary: Group of 11 broke into the embassy in Port-au-Prince the day after the killing. TAIPEI-Eleven of the suspects in the assassination of Haiti's president broke into Taiwan's embassy in Port-au-Prince the day after the incident and were arrested there, Taiwan's Foreign Ministry said Friday.

title: Index of U.S.-Listed Chinese Firms Falls to Lowest Point in Over a Year
summary: Chinese tech companies are being scrutinized by Beijing. A new wave of regulatory scrutiny for China's technology companies has helped send an index of U.S.-traded Chinese stocks to its lowest point in more than a year.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: With Hollywood Production in Overdrive, the Soundstage Is a Hot Commodity
summary: The surge in new movies and TV shows has touched off a scramble for places to film. Empty office space, abandoned malls and even a shuttered Sears store-apparently all the world really is a stage.. There is one going up in Buffalo, and another planned for Missoula. The South Side of Chicago is getting one, and so are Seattle and Spokane. Oklahoma City just opened one, and Los Angeles is getting at least a half-dozen more.

title: Pfizer to Ask Regulators to Authorize Covid-19 Vaccine Booster
summary: Company and partner BioNTech are also developing an updated version of their vaccine to better protect against Delta variant. Pfizer Inc. will seek clearance from U.S. regulators in coming weeks to distribute a booster shot of its Covid-19 vaccine to heighten protection against infections, as new virus strains rise.

title: China Car Sales Fall With Chips in Short Supply
summary: June sales were down 5.1% from a year earlier, ending an 11-month growth streak. China's car sales snapped an 11-month streak of year-over-year growth as demand bolstered by a strong economic recovery collided with a global semiconductor shortage.

title: Haiti Authorities Intensify Manhunt After President's Assassination
summary: Interim prime minister calls on citizens to round up suspects. Haiti's interim prime minister said his government is intensifying a manhunt in the aftermath of the assassination of President Jovenel Moïse, arresting several suspects believed to have participated in a killing that came as gang violence had been sharply escalating.

title: Avenatti Sentenced to 2½ Years for Trying to Extort Nike
summary: Prison term caps a public downfall for the California lawyer who represented Stormy Daniels in her legal battles with former President Donald Trump. Michael Avenatti was sentenced Thursday to 2½ years in prison for trying to extort Nike Inc. for more than $20 million, capping the public downfall of a celebrity lawyer whose star turn as Stormy Daniels's pugnacious lawyer ended in criminal charges.
